event.name: Wordsmithy
event.subject: Cultural
event.oneline_desc: What ho, budding Wordsmiths! Are you up for some essay-crafting?

event.name: Carl Zeiss Pratikṛti
event.subject: Cultural
event.oneline_desc: Search for the ultimate shutterbug. How good are you at arresting time, immortalizing moments and photographing beauty lurking in the ordinary?

desc.para:
While there is perhaps a province in which the photograph can tell us nothing more than what we see with our own eyes, there is another in which it proves to us how little our eyes permit us to see.
―Dorothea Lange

Pravega is on the lookout for the ultimate shutterbug! How good are you at arresting time in its tracks, immortalizing moments and unraveling hidden beauties in the ordinary? Pratikriti is our theme based online photography competition, sponsored by Carl Zeiss. Please see the rules below for more details. Register now!
Theme: prakṛti ke raṅg/Colors of Nature

The competition is over. Winners are announed!
1st Prize: Abhinav Jain
2nd Prize: Akash Sonawane
3rd Prize: Kishore Ranganath R


Congratulations to the winners!

Co-ordinator:
Madhwesh C. R.
madhwesh@pravega.org

Pratikṛti is a single theme based competition.
Participants need to register on pravega.org and for this event (the register button above).

Aravind Rao

event.name: Master the Tides
event.subject: PhysicsGONE
event.oneline_desc: Navigate a raft through the twist and turns of a turbulent water course.

desc.para: Pravega has created its own torrential tributary—a scaled-down version of a river-rafting course that will be the hardest test a man-made vessel ever saw. This event will attract engineers who can both think as well as work with their hands and can implement the difficult concepts of fluid dynamics in reality. Participants are required to construct a raft-like platform that is capable of navigating the water-track. May the best shipwright win!

Co-ordinator:
Shreyas Gupta
shreyas@pravega.org

rules_list.rule: The objective is to create a course-worthy raft using small homeopathy bottles, paper, thread, feviquick, glue and sticks.

Registration may be online or onsite, with a first-come-first-serve basis that favours online registrations. For online registration, the team is required to solve 10 multiple-choice questions online.
A team may consist of a maximum of two members.
Participants may bring homemade platforms or make them on the spot; materials will be provided.
A 6 ft × 4 ft sized water track having scaled up design of the miniature model will be elevated above a tub of water.

A cube of dimensions 1"×1"×1" and average density 2.4 g/cc will have to be transported as cargo on the raft along the course of the track. The top half of the cube should be uncovered. This cube is placed by the organizer as indicated by the participating team.

One hour is given for making or modifying the platform. The platforms may not be modified after commencement of the trials. If a team so wishes, they may opt for at most one second attempt.The platform may be modified during the thirty minutes between the two sets of trials.

The score per run is calculated by the following formula:
T0 − T + k × Checkpoints + Bonus − Penalty
where T0 and k are some appropriate constants, T is the time taken for this run, and the bonus and penalty are based on the discretion of the judges.

If the team has chosen for a second attempt, their score is calculated by the following formula:
1/100 × ((Attempt 1 Score) × x − (Attempt 2 Score) × (1−x))
The value of x is chosen by the team, must lie between 25 and 75, and must be chosen between the two trials. The scores per attempt are determined by the formula in point 8.

desc.para: Heard of dumb charades in biology? With the usage of elements of drama and mime, you would be expected to enact out biological terms and phenomena, while your team guesses the word. You cannot split any word where the split-up word itself isn't a biological term itself. All the rounds will have variations of this general theme of biology and theatre intertwined together.
So buckle up and get ready to unleash the actor in you!

siddharth@pravega.org

rules_list.rule: Each team should consist of exactly 4 members.
The participants are not allowed to use any form of written or spoken language to express the topic. They can only use mime, acting and hand movements to describe the biological phenomena.
Sign language communication between actor and guesser is allowed. However, usage of syllables, phonetics or alphabets through any signalling method would lead to instant disqualification.

The participants cannot split the words into any part, until and unless the split words itself is a completely meaningful biological term. If the splitting of a word results in two smaller words, only one of which is a biological term, then the actor can only enact out the sub-word with biological meaning.

The teams have to send us a set of 20 enactable biological terms (phenomena) by 29th January, 2014 to biology@pravega.org. 10 topics will be reselected from this list and be given back to the team for usage in one of the rounds.
There will be three rounds in total.

In the first round, any one person from each team will have to act out words written on flash cards, one after the other for 2 minutes, while the audience has to guess. The team which skips the least number of words in the set of ordered flash cards, and makes the audience correctly guess the maximum number of words over a duration of 2 minutes, scores the most points.

In the second round, all four members of a team will be given a biological phenomenon to act out together, while the other teams would try to guess the phenomena. The team which guesses the phenomena correctly would score some points, and the team enacting out would also score some points.

In the third round, any one member of a team will be given a biological term, which he has enact out to the second member of his team, with both members remaining completely mute, while the third and fourth members are physically isolated from the stage. Then, the second member enacts out the topic to the third member with both members allowed to communicate via sign language, while the fourth member is still far away. Finally, the third member enacts the word out to the fourth member, with the last member being allowed to vocally speak out the words while guessing them. The aim of this round is to ensure that the word given to first person reaches the last person intact! The teams would be judged on their speed, accuracy, creative use of acting/mime skills, as well as coordination.
The points of each round will be summed in total. The team with the most points at the end of the 3 rounds would win the event.

desc.para: "What's Chindogu?", you ask? Well, Wikipedia says: Chindogu is the Japanese art of inventing ingenious everyday gadgets that, on the face of it, seem like an ideal solution to a particular problem. However, Chindogu has a distinctive feature: anyone actually attempting to use one of these inventions would find that it causes so many new problems, or such significant social embarrassment, that effectively it has no utility whatsoever. Thus, Chindogu are sometimes described as "unuseless" - that is, they cannot be regarded as "useless" in an absolute sense, since they do actually solve a problem; however, in practical terms, they cannot positively be called "useful".

Think inventing something useful is hard? Well, inventing something un-useless is harder still! Pravega challenges you to invent something wacky, cool and completely un-useless using any material that you can think of. Remember: the crazier, the wackier, the better!
